Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2013 07:02PM AndreaJ50 wrote: Tam178 and Ladydi950 welcome aboard! I was recently diagnosed, so I understand what you are feeling now. I will give you the same advice I was given by many ladies whose journey started before ours; Breath!! It is overwhelming at first, and scary. But it is unbelievable how many people will reach out to help you along. Take the help that they offer, and someday you will help others. Ladydi950, I too opted for a lumpectomy, for the same reasons that you stated. I also hope it is the right choice. Baby steps. Looks like we are starting this journey together. Hugs to you both! (PS Tam178 I am Canadian too, but living in USA)
Posts.Title: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma - age 36.... oh crap!! Tam178 AndreaJ50

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2015 03:41PM AndreaJ50 wrote: Windingshores sending good thoughts your way for your surgery. Doing one at a time might be easier on your system. Please keep in touch. Take care
Posts.Title: anyone have a cold just before surgery? windingshores AndreaJ50

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2015 02:46AM AndreaJ50 wrote: I had a slight cold that started a few days before surgery. lt felt more like allergies really. By the day of surgery I had a bit of a cough from post nasal drip. Doc listened to my chest and said no problem. Everything went as planned. Best of luck for you tomorrow!
Posts.Title: anyone have a cold just before surgery? windingshores AndreaJ50

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2015 05:11AM AndreaJ50 wrote: Kiks1, I am sorry you are in the club now. But at least you will never be alone, there are so many ladies here to help you through this. It is a scary time for sure. We have all been in the position you are in. Once you have a full diagnosis and treatment plan it gets easier. Truly!! I found I went through the stages of grief after my dx. Once I recognized this it made it easier to cope. When I was feeling down I would read the posts from long term survivors. It was very encouraging.I also started binge watching Netflix to take my mind off things. Hugs,
Posts.Title: Going down the abyss Kiks1 Kiks1

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2014 07:08AM AndreaJ50 wrote: I am sorry you are both going through this. Everyone one here has been at the point you are at right now, and can relate to how you are feeling. Everyone told me it would get easier once a plan was put in place. And you know what...they were right.  If you need some meds to help with the anxiety Get Them!!! Vent on this forum, ask questions , and most definitely visit the Survival Stories section. You have an inner strength you haven't even begun to tap yet... It will come. And now just breathe!! Take care, Andrea
Posts.Title: IDC Coopdizzle Kalonis52

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2013 04:36AM AndreaJ50 wrote: I have surgery today. Lumpectomy and sentinel node dissection. Trying to just breathe! Can't wait to get the cancer out!! Today is a good day!!
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2013 03:57PM AndreaJ50 wrote: NjMom3, don't worry about the nuclear med procedure. I honestly felt nothing . Granted I don't have much feeling in my breast anyway, but I would do it again in a heartbeat if I had to. They will treat you very well I am sure. If you are worries about nausea and vomiting post op (as I did) make it real clear to Anesthetist. Also ask them to put a patch behind your ear during surgery because it can take up to 90 min to take effect (I wish they had done that for me). Best wishes. Cancer sucks!! But the people on this board make it easier to deal with. Take care, Andrea
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 06:59PM AndreaJ50 wrote: welcome Greentennessee, It sure sounds like there is a bit for the doctors to figure out. Luckily you got a biopsy and the pathologist report will clear up the confusion.  I have had other types of biopsies, but not stereotactic . Hopefully you won't have to wait long for the results. This is the worst part I think, waiting for results. Our minds question every little nuance and fill in the blanks. Try to distract yourself if you can while you await the news. I am not much help, sorry, but I will hope for good news. Also it probably would help to repost this under a new thread so that more people will see it and not confuse it with the person who started this particular thread. Take care, Andrea
Posts.Title: I'm scared too ... why such little support for me?! dree2014 marie5890

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 07:06PM AndreaJ50 wrote: dree2014 I am sorry you feel let down. I know it wasn't intentional. I had a similar thing happen to me once, early in my journey, and felt alone. Then a few days later suddenly people started responding. Time seems to stand still when you are waiting for a response.  We are here for each other. But remember, like you we all have burdens to bear, and people that need us to be there for them, not to mention we all live in different time zones.  Some of the greatest lessons cancer teaches us are patience and tolerance. Take care, Andrea
Posts.Title: I'm scared too ... why such little support for me?! dree2014 marie5890

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2014 09:12PM AndreaJ50 wrote: Jennie93 and Holeinone, thank you for your replies. You know, my dad had a bacterial ulcer many years ago and he also said that what I had could be an ulcer too. Then my GI did and endoscopy and took biopsies of my stomach and ruled that out. But I am not convinced. I didn't realize there was a blood test I could get that would tell me. The pain is definitely "gnawing". I get another endoscope in June. I do have a small hiatus hernia, but that is not  near the pain. I have been on Omeprazole since January for heartburn.  I will follow up on this and check again for ulcers. Thank you again. Take care, Andrea
Posts.Title: Why does my abdomen hurt? AndreaJ50 AndreaJ50

Posts.Content: AndreaJ50 wrote: I went to the doctor in Sept 2013 with the complaint of mild pain in my upper right abdomen (2 months prior to BC DX ) Doctor thought I might have diverticulosis and sent me for CT scan and put me on meds. CT showed no diverticulosis, no masses in liver, gallbladder, pancreas, etc. just follicular cysts on both ovaries. I went to GI and had HIDA test for gallbladder and liver function (came back clear) and colonoscopy and endoscopy were both good. But my abdomen (to the right of my stomach)!still hurts, especially when I am hungry. Long winded , sorry...does this sound like it could be mets? Or would those tests have ruled that out? Thanks! Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2014 05:55AM AndreaJ50 wrote: just finished fifth week of Rads!! Only 3 more full breast and 5 boosts left. I got very pink at the start of week five, but no sores or oozing so far. I use Udderly Smooth lotion (as per RO suggestion: from Dollar store) and also Aquafor on nipple and underboob. Tech said my skin was holding up extremely well. I'm not complaining. Just hoping it doesn't get any worse. Gentle hugs for everyone going through Rads right now.

Posts.Title: Winter 2013-2014 Rads TeamKim mouse9587

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2014 12:50PM AndreaJ50 wrote: Well it was bound to happen. Posts.Title: Winter 2013-2014 Rads TeamKim mouse9587

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2014 12:33PM AndreaJ50 wrote: Hi NSwrites, Not sure if enlarged nodes mean cancer involvement in your case, but I know many people (my son included) that have enlarged lymph nodes for reasons other than cancer. Waiting is always the hardest part. But try not to read too much Into it at this point. On a side note: I just returned from spending my summer in Alberta (my home) and it was wonderful! Take care! Andrea
Posts.Title: Confused about lymph nodes? NSwrites Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2013 11:48AM AndreaJ50 wrote: this is going to sound weird....but if you have something like Netflix or on Demand watch whole seasons of a show you have never seen before. I watched all of season 1 of Orange is the New Black in three days. It transported me and totally took my mind off of worrying. Of course the encouragement of all the lovely ladies on this forum has helped tremendously too! But distraction is a wonderful tool. I also keep taking my dogs for short walks. Just a change of scenery takes my mind off of it for a while. If we had an Indoor pool anywhere near here I would go swimming too. Bake, cook, clean, read a book, knit, crochet, play the piano... Anything to divert your thoughts... Even for a short time helps. I have my first biopsy tomorrow. And these have been helping me. P.S. if you do watch Orange is the New Black and want to chat about it... Or anything else just PM me. Take care Andrea

Posts.Title: In shock bennymuffins websister

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2013 08:22PM AndreaJ50 wrote: Last fall my daughter had a fibroadenoma removed and developed a hematoma. It wouldn't dissolve on its own and after many weeks she went to the doctor to have it drained. The wound wasn't healing up, but there was no infection so the doctor showed her how to manually "milk" the area to drain it herself. The next day she tried that and a blood clot burst out of her breast. After that it cleared up and healed . Gross, I know, sorry. But my point is that your hematoma might not be reansorbing and might need some help. Good luck!
Posts.Title: hematoma (huge) after core biopsy - botched PhyllisCC Mimikay23

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2014 06:56AM AndreaJ50 wrote: I went in today for my set up appointment. Did all the measurements and tattoos. The responses I got were hilarious. So I came clean. Then I said they were blue dots that looked like the Earth from outer space. Reminds me of the episode where Phoebe and Rachel get tattoos!!

The techs told me to wait until I see burns, and the RO told me to start with cream right away. I am in day 15/33 today and so far there is no change in my skin. I just wondered what the cream does before your skin reacts. And about how long now before I could expect skin changes. I know it is different for everyone, but just wondered. Thanks ladies!
Posts.Title: Winter 2013-2014 Rads TeamKim mouse9587

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2014 06:08AM AndreaJ50 wrote: Mimi, our journeys seem very similar. I had my first lumpectomy three days before you, but had two more reincisions (and an excisional biopsy on other breast) as well.  I was a DD before, and even though I had  plenty   to work with they ended up taking a large portion out of one side. I remember just after surgery thinking I looked like a sock with a ball in it, lol. But it has filled back up (with fluid I assume) and looks pretty much the same as before. All through radiation I was hoping my breast would get smaller. But I finished rads in April and there has been minimal change.  How much smaller is your breast since Rads? My one nipple has changed and toughened, but other wise not difference. Take care, Andrea

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2014 11:16PM AndreaJ50 wrote: Thank you everyone. I will sleep better tonight...well not really because the pain hasn't subsided. But at least when it keeps me awake in the wee hours I won't be thinking the worst. Doc wants me to see a spine specialist. It's not that bad yet! If it is the Tamoxifen causing it I will just have to get used to it. Might find out more when I see my Oncologist in Sept. Kidneystone hasn't been too bad really... It was much worse when I thought it was Liver Mets....I am seeing a pattern here!!! I miss the days when every ache and pain wasn't suspect. Doubt I will get my DH anywhere near a scalpel. Might try the bricks after all, lol. Take care everyone and have a peaceful night! Still smiling from that photo of the chick!! Hugs all around! Andrea

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2015 05:25PM AndreaJ50 wrote: thank you Jo. I saw breast surgeon this morning. She thinks it came on too quickly to be angio. She sent me over for mammo and U/S. Radiologist said they looked good but she was concerned about IBC. She said if antibiotics dont ckear it up I shoukd have a biopsy.
Posts.Title: Secondary Angiosarcoma of the Breast JO-5 JO-5

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2015 05:31PM AndreaJ50 wrote: I saw my MO today. She said that she doesnt think it is angio or IBC. She said it looks to her like I have lymphadema in my breast and it has burst blood vessels. She has not seen ine that covered so much if the breast befire. But she has seen it in another patient ended up getting a mastectomy. I am still on antibiotics in case the LE caused an infection. But I am also booked in at the LE clinic (have to wait a month). If it doesn't clear up they will do a biopsy. Huge sigh of relief!!! Anything but cancer please and thank you!!!
Posts.Title: Secondary Angiosarcoma of the Breast JO-5 JO-5

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2013 09:45PM AndreaJ50 wrote: thank you for such quick replies! I have had lousy response to general before, so I did tell the anesthesiologist that I vomit afterwards. They said they would give me meds to counteract the nausea, but either they forgot or they didn't work.. They said they would put a patch behind my ear and they forgot to. When I was given one several hours later it eased things pretty quickly. They gave me an antiemetic in recovery but it made my head so dizzy it was actually worse. I think the fact that I couldn't take a deep breath made it worse. A few years ago I had sinus surgery and whatever they used that time worked perfectly!! I think I will opt for twilight next time. Wish me luck, lol.

Posts.Title: Highly Suggestive of Malignancy AlienWish angelaisscared

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2014 10:47PM AndreaJ50 wrote: I am Canadian andI grew up in Canada and had all my children there, but have lived in the USA for the past 6 years. My daughters are nurses there and my father was an X-ray manager for most of his life.  I have to say I am so thankful that I have good insurance and live here in the States. The medical care I receive is top notch. Canada used to have a great Health care system, and Alberta's was the best. But I am sad to day that is not the case anymore. Stupid politics!!! My dad had to wait 11 months then 8 months to have each cataract done. My mother waited two years for back surgery. And my daughter had to wait 18 months for allergy testing. We ended up moving to Michigan two months before her allergist appointment. And when we arrived she saw an allergist in 4 days!!! The doctors thought my mom had bleeding in her brain in 2014 when she was brought by ambulance to ER one night and so they scheduled an appointment with a neurologist....eleven months later!!!! I hope where you live you are getting the best care!

The thought of living without hot baths saddens me. Bur I will have to accept it.

Posts.Content: AndreaJ50 wrote: I had a lumpectomy last week and reacted terribly to anesthetic. I was vomiting as I awoke and continued to be ill for several hours. The whole idea of ever going through that again terrifies me. So, today I got my pathology results. The margins were poor. The surgeon needs to go in and  take out more.  She said they could use "twilight"  I.V. anesthetic and freezing.But they would have the anesthesiologist in the room in case they had to put me under general. Wondering if anyone else has had their lumpectomy done this way. And what they thought of it compares to general anesthesia. Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2013 09:01PM AndreaJ50 wrote: thank you everyone. I am remarkably calm now. When I first went into the surgeon's office I was told I had an in situ and infiltrating ductal carcinoma with moderate to good differentiation. Then I found out it had estrogen and progesterone receptors. No word on her-2 yet. I can book surgery for mid December but I need to decide between mastectomy and lumpectomy. It's a lot to take in. Once I broke the news to my love ones it was easier to deal with. Now it's my new normal.
